ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to talk about food, business conversations, making speeches, being a guest in a Chinese home, etc.
I furthered my study of the Chinese language in terms of vocabulary, grammar, and culture.
I developed a better understanding of Chinese and of the language.
I developed skills regarding all 4 aspects (R,L, S, W) of Chinese.
I strengthened my grasp of complex grammar structures, broadened my vocabulary, and grew more confident in my Chinese speaking ability.
Wider Chinese vocabulary, greater confidence in composing and understanding complex Chinese sentences.
My Chinese speaking and writing abilities increased tremendously. Speaking felt much more natural and reading was easy!

Developed greater oral and aural skills. I can now have more organic/spontaneous interactions about a variety of subjects in Chinese. Also have a better knowledge of vocabulary related to travel/study abroad/Chinese culture which is helpful.

I learned to be more fluent in speaking

My grammar improved

my reading improved

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the structure of the class is very good. The professors are also great.
This course provides an in-depth study of the Chinese language and provides a variety of assesments to test this knowlede, but this meant that there was a significant amount of work.
Incredible. Well organized.

I think the David and Helen in China textbook is a great learning tool. Not only do the lessons introduce useful grammar and vocabulary, the grammar exercises and word usage sections are a great learning tool. A weakness would be that, at least when complex grammar structures are introduced, it would be useful to have some instruction in English so we can actually figure out how the grammar patterns are supposed to work.
Strengths: Fantastic teacher engagement, well-planned lessons, good balance of work.

STRENGTH: All-around improvement in your skills. Supportive professors. Small class sizes. Supplementary events.
WEAKNESS: Very time consuming course with nightly assignments and weekly partner oral projects (though this is true of any language/Chinese class at Yale)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you are interested in continuing Chinese. It is very similar to 130
I would recommend this course to people want to learn about Chinese.
Absolutely. Wang lao shi is phenomenal

I took this class even after completing my language requirement, and Im really happy I did. I feel way more comfortable with Chinese than I did after completing 130, and the level of difficulty is quite similar.
Yes, if you want to improve your Chinese fluency this course is a good choice.
Absolutely!! This is an amazing course. You will learn so much and enjoy it so much
Absolutely! Especially if you are planning to continue your Chinese education at Yale or considering China for post-grad.
Yes
